data.title: Bilingual Arithmetic
data.statement:
All your friends speak more than one language, and they try to teach you arithmetic.

But it's all so confusing because they tend to use multiple languages in the same equation !!
It's beaucoup loco !!

For convenience, 1 to 10 (in every language they know) is already provided in the stub.

Do the math, to find [[theAnswer]]




~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Source:
Foreign words are from 
https://mathlair.allfunandgames.ca/languages.php
with some corrections/additions from Codingamer Rafarafa

testCases.title: Test 1
testCases.testIn:
4
(1) uno + two
(2) five * tri
(3) octo / quatre
(4) dix - cinco

testCases.title: Validator 1
testCases.testIn:
5
(1) deux * nio
(2) októ + six
(3) trois - sei
(4) nueve / odin
(5) deg + sitta

testCases.testIn:

(4) seis * lau

(6) sapta * déka
(7) téssera * trayah
(8) ennéa * uno
(9) tisa'a + deux
(10) októ + sześć
(11) sex + pump

data.constraints:
All input numbers are 1 to 10 and are provided in the stub
Everything is an integer
You will never have to round
data.stubGenerator:
read howMany:int
loop howMany read equation:string(30)
write Do the math

STATEMENT
English: one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten
German: eins, zwei, drei, vier, fünf, sechs, sieben, acht, neun, zehn
Swedish: ett, två, tre, fyra, fem, sex, sju, åtta, nio, tio
Norwegian: en, to, tre, fire, fem, seks, syv, åtte, ni, ti
French: un, deux, trois, quatre, cinq, six, sept, huit, neuf, dix
Italian: uno, due, tre, quattro, cinque, sei, sette, otto, nove, dieci
Spanish: uno, dos, tres, cuatro, cinco, seis, siete, ocho, nueve, diez
Portuguese: um, dois, três, quatro, cinco, seis, sete, oito, nove, dez
Catalan: un, dos, tres, quatre, cinc, sis, set, vuit, nou, deu
Latin: unus, duo, tres, quattor, quinque, sex, septem, octo, novem, decem
Russian: odin, dva, tri, chetyre, pyat', shest', sem', vosem', devyat', desyat'
Polish: jeden, dwa, trzy, cztery, pięć, sześć, siedem, osiem, dziewięć, dziesięć
Welsh: un, dau, tri, pedwar, pump, chwech, saith, wyth, naw, deg
AncientGreek: eîs, dúo, treîs, téssares, pénte, hex, heptá, októ, ennéa, déka
ModernGreek: éna, dúo, tría, téssera, pénte, éxi, eptá, októ, ennéa, déka
Finnish: yksi, kaksi, kolme, neljä, viisi, kuusi, seitsemän, kahdeksan, yhdeksan, kymmenen
Basque: bat, bi, hiru, lau, bost, sei, zazpi, zortzi, beheratzi, hamar
Sanskrit: ekab, dvi, trayah, chatvarah, pancha, shash, sapta, ashta, nava, dasha
Swahili: moja, bili, tatu, 'nne, tano, sita, sabbah, nanne, tissa, kumi
Arabic: wahed, ithnain, thelatha, arba'a, hamza, sitta, seba'a, themania, tisa'a, ashara
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> An integer, [[howMany]] how many equations will follow
<<Next [[howMany]] Lines:>> A string, consisting of a {{(}}[[sequentialOrderNumber]]{{)}}, followed by the [[equation]], which is always a number, followed by one of the 4 basic arithmetic operators ({{ + - * / }}), followed by another number, all separated by a space

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

All your friends speak more than one language, and they try to teach you arithmetic.

But it's all so confusing because they tend to use multiple languages in the same equation !!
It's beaucoup loco !!

For convenience, 1 to 10 (in every language they know) is already provided in the stub.

Do the math, to find theAnswer




~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Source:
Foreign words are from
https://mathlair.allfunandgames.ca/languages.php
with some corrections/additions from Codingamer Rafarafa
Input
Line 1: An integer, howMany how many equations will follow
Next howMany Lines: A string, consisting of a (sequentialOrderNumber), followed by the equation, which is always a number, followed by one of the 4 basic arithmetic operators ( + - * / ), followed by another number, all separated by a space
Output
howMany Lines: (sequentialOrderNumber) theAnswer, separated by a space
Constraints
All input numbers are 1 to 10 and are provided in the stub
Everything is an integer
You will never have to round
Example
Input
4
(1) uno + two
(2) five * tri
(3) octo / quatre
(4) dix - cinco
Output
(1) 3
(2) 15
(3) 2
(4) 5
